DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: ADCS
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category refers to the various functions an ADCS implements. It is to be used for the ADCS capability description.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataDependencies
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this part covers the physical dependencies between signals.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataFlow
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category refers to the data processing. It should probably be renamed accordingly. It should define and organize the different types of processing encountered during drilling operations. A Thursday session was devoted to those items. Note that in the current version, control flow is also included: a controller is seen as a special type of processing unit, that generates commands based on measurements and set-points. This can of course be modified if deemed necessary. Note also that transmission is included there as well. A telemetry system is seen as a processing unit that only duplicates a signal, and a delay is associated to the duplication process. While this is a useful way of looking at telemetry, it is probably not intuitive enough.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataProviders
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: description of the different actors involved in the well construction process

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataTransmission
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category contains all nouns and verbs used to describe the rig's telemetry, for each signal. Downhole telemetry has focus.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DataValidity
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category contains all the nouns and verbs used to described the validity of signals. Some signals are for example only valid while off-slips, downhole signals transmitted via mud-pulse telemetry require circulation.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingDataSemantics
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this is the part associated to the signal's description themselves. Dimensionality, data type are the main items to be described.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingEquipment
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: in this category fall all the standard equipment encountered on a drilling rig. Note that the goal of the vocabulary is not to provide a detailed description of the rig. Therefore we only consider nouns that can help providing a signal context.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DrillingIncident
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category refers mostly to the description of drilling incidents.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: DWISSemantics
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: definitions of the base noun and verb. All verbs and nouns in the DWIS vocabulary are children of those.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: EndPoints
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this is the part associated to the description of external end-points.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Hydraulics
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this part refers to the hydraulic circuit, and should only contain the "abstract" or conceptual part of the vocabulary. Additional nouns coming from the drilling equipment category will be used when constructing the semantic graphs.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: MechanicalModel
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: specialized vocabulary for the modelling of the drilling mechanics. Covers in particular the so-called torque and drag models

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Mechanics
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this part refers to the mechanical circuit, and should only contain the "abstract" or conceptual part of the vocabulary. Additional nouns coming from the drilling equipment category will be used when constructing the semantic graphs.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Model
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: high level and generic vocabulary for mathematical models of the drilling process

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: PhysicalLocation
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category contains the vocabulary necessary to specify the location of various items on a rig. Coordinate systems are the main element here.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: TimeManagement
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category referes mostly to the description of the various clocks that can be encoutered on a rig, and their synchronization status with respect to each other.

DefinitionSetHeaders.Name: Uncertainty
DefinitionSetHeaders.SetDescription: this category contains the nouns and verbs required to describe the various types of uncertainty attached to drilling signals. Uncertainties can be related to sensor characteristics, calculations, model calibration, data assimilation.

Nouns.Name: ComputedState
Nouns.Description: A state represents the current configuation of a system.

Nouns.Name: ComputationUnit
Nouns.Description: Denotes a complex computation unit, typically based on advanced numerical modeling

Nouns.Name: MeasurementDevice
Nouns.Description: Denotes a physical sensor

Nouns.Name: Transformation
Nouns.Description: Represents a transformation applied to some signals that produces other signals

Nouns.Name: DirectTransformation
Nouns.Description: Direct transformations are performed using only the current value of their inputs, time is not involved

Nouns.Name: SignalProcessingUnit
Nouns.Description: Represent any signal processing applied prior to the distribution of the considered signal. Signal processing refers to e.g. noise removal, filtering,..

Nouns.Name: TimeBasedTransformation
Nouns.Description: Transformations that apply only to time series: time derivations, time integration, averaging...

Nouns.Name: DataProvider
Nouns.Description: A data provider is any sources for data

Nouns.Name: OperatingCompany
Nouns.Description: An operating company is an entity that holds the rights to explore, develop, and produce hydrocarbon resources from a particular oil or gas field or lease

Nouns.Name: ServiceCompany
Nouns.Description: A service company is an entity that provides services during the well construction.

Nouns.Name: DirectionalServiceCompany
Nouns.Description: A directional service company is an entity that provides services for downhole directional drilling and downhole measurements.

Nouns.Name: DrillingFluidProvider
Nouns.Description: A drilling fluid provider is a company that provides and maintains the drilling fluids during well construction.

Nouns.Name: LoggingServiceCompany
Nouns.Description: A logging service company is an entity that gathers measured information during well construction.

Nouns.Name: DataAnalysisServiceCompany
Nouns.Description: A data analysis service company is an entity that analyses measured data and provide new information from these measurements.

Nouns.Name: DWISInternalService
Nouns.Description: A DWIS internal service is an internal component of the DWIS infrastructure that generates information that can be used by any systems connected to the DWIS infrastructure.

Nouns.Name: Telemetry
Nouns.Description: Technology used for transferring the data from its main origin.

Nouns.Name: DownHoleTelemetry
Examples: Technology that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface.

Nouns.Name: MudPulseTelemetry
Nouns.Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via pressure pulses sent trough the drilling fluid.

Nouns.Name: ElectromagneticTelemetry
Nouns.Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via electromagnetic waves sent trough the drilling formation.
Examples: APS SureShot-EM, NOV BlackStar II EM MWD

Nouns.Name: WiredPipeTelemetry
Nouns.Description: A method that allows transfer of downhole data to the surface via electrical connections through the drill string.
Examples: Intelliserv Wired Drill Pipe, Reelwell DualLink

Nouns.Name: TopSideTelemetry
Nouns.Description: Method that allows transfer of data from surface systems.

Nouns.Name: NormalizedDataType
Nouns.Description: between 0 and 1

Nouns.Name: DrillingDataPoint
Nouns.Description: Main type of DDHub data. Represents a drilling signal.

Nouns.Name: BitDepth
Nouns.Description: Curvilinear abscissa of the bottom of the bit, in the reference frame centered in the wellbore.

Nouns.Name: Measurement
Nouns.Description: The noun Measurement represents individuals that are measured by some instrument and which value can be compared with another measurement.

Nouns.Name: DrillingSignal
Nouns.Description: Data structure used to store the streaming drilling data.

NounAttributes.Name: TimeStampAtSource
NounAttributes.Description: this is a UTC date-time value corresponding to the time at which the value has been taken.

NounAttributes.Name: TimeStampAcquisition
NounAttributes.Description: this is a UTC date-time value at which the value has been acquired by the data acquisition system.

Nouns.Name: DWISNoun
Nouns.Description: Nouns refer to the nature of a node in the graph. Implicitely a noun refers to a "is a" relation between the instance node and the noun. This is the root class for all the nouns defined in the DWIS vocabulary.
Examples: `DWISNoun` is not really intended to be used directly neither when defining semantic facts nor in sparql queries.

NounAttributes.Name: LeftToRight
NounAttributes.Description: Indicates whether the fluid can flow from the left branch to the right branch though the junction

NounAttributes.Name: RightToLeft
NounAttributes.Description: Indicates whether the fluid can flow from the right branch to the left branch though the junction

Nouns.Name: DrillStemMechanicalModel
Nouns.Description: A mechanical model for a drill-stem. Another name for drill-stem mechanical models is a torque and drag model.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffnessType
Nouns.Description: A description of how the drill-stem stiffness is modelled.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalSoftModel
Nouns.Description: An infinitively soft model assumes that the drill-stem deforms without any resistance when compressive loads are applied.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModel
Nouns.Description: A stiff mechanical model considers that the drill-stem can deform laterally when put in compression.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModelAssumedContacts
Nouns.DisplayName: Mechanical stiff model with assumed contacts
Nouns.Description: Such a stiff mechanical model presuposes the position of the contact points.

Nouns.Name: MechanicalStiffModelEstimatedContacts
Nouns.DisplayName: Mechanical stiff model with estimated contacts
Nouns.Description: Such a stiff mechanical model estimates the position of the contact points.

Nouns.Name: TangencyLength
Nouns.Description: the position along the drill-string, counted from the bit, from which we can consider that the pipes direction is tangential with the borehole direction.

Nouns.Name: MathematicalModel
Nouns.Description: A model for which the state variables do not change with time.

Nouns.Name: SteadyStateModel
Nouns.Description: A model for which the state variables do not change with time.

Nouns.Name: TransientModel
Nouns.Description: A model for which the state variables changes with time.

Nouns.Name: ModelledDegreeOfFreedom
Nouns.Description: In physics and chemistry, a degree of freedom is an independent physical parameter in the formal description of the state of a physical system. A model may account for some or all of the degrees of freedom of the physical system.

Nouns.Name: AxialModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the axial movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the axial velocity of fluid inside a pipe or an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the axial displacement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: RotationalModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the rotational movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of pipe rotation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the rotational movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: LateralModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the lateral movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the lateral pipe displacement on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the lateral  movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: RadialModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the radial movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the radial pipe displacement on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the radial  movement of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: AngularLateralModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the angular lateral movement of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe wobbling on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the wobbling of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: TangentialModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the change of tangential direction of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: VerticalOndulationModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the change of inclination of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe vertical ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the vertical ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: HorizontalOndulationModelling
Nouns.Description: The model accounts for the change of azimuth of some parts of the physical system.
Examples: A hydraulic model accounts for the effect of the pipe horizontal ondulation on the fluid velocity in an annulus. A torque and drag model accounts for the horizontal ondulation of a drill-stem.

Nouns.Name: ModellingDimensions
Nouns.Description: The number of dimensions that are accounted by the model

Nouns.Name: OneDModelling
Nouns.Description: The model only accounts for one dimension
Examples: A hydraulic model only considers the axial direction for the flow in a pipe and in an annulus.

Nouns.Name: TwoDModelling
Nouns.Description: The model only accounts for two dimensions
Examples: A hydraulic calculation considers the fluid velocity field in a cross-section but does not consider the axial direction. A heat transfer model considers the radial and axial heat transfer but assumes complete angular symmetry.

Nouns.Name: ThreeDModelling
Nouns.Description: The model only accounts for three dimensions
Examples: A hydraulic calculation considers the fluid velocity field in a cross-section and in the axial direction. A heat transfer model considers the radial, angular and axial heat transfer.

Nouns.Name: ModellingDiscretization
Nouns.Description: A characteristic of the discretization made by the model.

Nouns.Name: BoundaryDiscretization
Nouns.Description: A model only considers the bounds of the physical system and does not apply any intermediate discretization.
Examples: The Kaasa model (https://doi.org/10.2118/143097-PA) is an example of hydraulic model that only accounts for the boundaries and does not utilize any intermediate discretization.

Nouns.Name: StrainWaveBasedDiscretization
Nouns.Description: A model can properly estimate values at the level of strain wave propagation.
Examples: A transient mechanical model that is compatible with modelling acoustic waves in the drill-string.

Nouns.Name: MassTransferBasedDiscretization
Nouns.Description: A model can properly estimate values at the level of mass transfer propagation.
Examples: A transient mechanical model that is compatible with modelling axial, rotationa and lateral drill-string displacement. A transient hydraulic model that is compatible with modelling fluid mass transfer inside the string and the annulus.

Nouns.Name: Location
Nouns.Description: Physical location for a signal. Refers to: 1) a reference frame (via the HasReferenceFrame relation), that works as a system of coordinates 2) an origin (of type Location) via the HasReferenceFrameOrigin relation.

Nouns.Name: ReferenceFrame
Nouns.Description: Represents a system of coordinates

Nouns.Name: MeasurableQuantity
Nouns.Description: Represents a quantity that allows meaningful comparisons.

NounAttributes.Name: ConversionFactorA
NounAttributes.Description: Unit conversion from SI unit is performed as:

NounAttributes.Name: ConversionFactorB
NounAttributes.Description: Unit conversion from SI unit is performed as:

Nouns.Name: UnitSystem
Nouns.Description: A set of associations between measurable quantities and units

Nouns.Name: Clock
Nouns.Description: Represents a clock

Nouns.Name: SignalUncertainty
Nouns.Description: Represent the uncertainty associated to a `DrillingDataPoint`.
Examples: This noun is not intended to be used directly in describing a signal. However, it can be useful when formulating a query and then it serves as a generic way to check if there are facts related to uncertainty description for a `DrillingDataPoint`.
This query returns all the `DrillingDataPoint` for which an uncertainty is given.

Nouns.Name: GaussianUncertainty
Nouns.Description: The uncertainty is represented by a Gaussian distribution, i.e., with a `Mean` and a `StandardDeviation`, $\mathcal{N}(\overline{x},{\sigma_{x}}^2)$ where $\overline{x}$ is the `Mean` value and $\sigma_{x}$ is the `StandardDeviation`.
Examples: In this example, `ddp#01` is a `DrillingDataPoint` that has an uncertainty `GU#01`, which is a Gaussian distribution that is described by a `Mean` value called `Mean#01` and a `StandardDeviation` value called `StdDev#01`. `Mean#01` is a live signal that is attached to `Signal#01`. Similarly `StdDev#01` is a live signal attached to `Signal#02`.

Nouns.Name: GenericUncertainty
Nouns.Description: The uncertainty is represented by a `Histogram`.
Examples: In this example, `ddp#01` is a `DrillingDataPoint` that has an uncertainty `GU#01`, which is a general probability distribution that is described by a histogram called `Histo#01`. `Histo#01` is a live signal that is attached to `Signal#01`.

Nouns.Name: MinMaxUncertainty
Nouns.Description: The uncertainty is represented by a uniform probability distribution between a `Min` and a `Max` value.
Examples: In this example, `ddp#01` is a `DrillingDataPoint` that has an uncertainty `GU#01`, which is a uniform probability distribution that is described by a `Min` value called `Min#01` and a `Max` value called `Max#01`. `Min#01` is a live signal that is attached to `Signal#01`. Similarly `Max#01` is a live signal attached to `Signal#02`.

Nouns.Name: FullScaleUncertainty

NounAttributes.Name: FullScale
NounAttributes.Description: The total range of measurement of the signal, i.e., $\left| max - min \right|$. The value is expected to be in the same physical quantity as the sensor value.

NounAttributes.Name: ProportionError
NounAttributes.Description: The proportion error on the signal. The value is expected to be a dimensionless physical quantity between 0 and 1 in SI unit. This proportion is applied to the `Fullscale` to obtain the standard deviation of the Gaussian probability distribution that describes the uncertainty of the signal. The mean value of that Gaussian distribution is the signal value.

Nouns.Description: The uncertainty on the signal is described as a Gaussian distribution with a standard deviation that is calculated using a proportion of the maximum range of the signal. The `Fullscale` or `ProportionError` can either be defined as attribute values, for example when they have fixed values, or using facts utilizing the verbs `HasFullScale` or repectively `HasProportionError` when these values may change through time.
Examples: In this example, `ddp#01` is a `DrillingDataPoint` that has an uncertainty `GU#01`, which is representing a sensor having a Gaussian probability distibution that is described using a `ProportionError` (called `ErrProp#01`) of a `FullScale` value called `FullScale#01`. `FullScale#01` is a static signal that is attached to `Signal#01`. Similarly `ErrProp#01` is a static signal attached to `Signal#02`.

Nouns.Name: SensorUncertainty

NounAttributes.Name: Accuracy
NounAttributes.Description: The standard deviation of the systematic bias component of the uncertainty of the sensor. The assumed mean value of the attached Gaussian distribution is the measured value. The value is expected to be in the same physical quantity as the sensor value.

NounAttributes.Name: Precision
NounAttributes.Description: The standard deviation of the repetitive error component of the uncertainty of the sensor. The assumed mean value of the attached Gaussian distribution is the measured value. The value is expected to be in the same physical quantity as the sensor value.

Nouns.Description: The uncertainty of the sensor is described by a systematic bias and repetitive error. The systematic bias is referred to as the `Accuracy` while the repetitive error is referred to as the `Precision`. The standard deviation of the overall Gaussian distribution is $\sqrt{\sigma^2{_a}+\sigma^2{_p}}$ where $\sigma_a$ is the accuracy and $\sigma_p$ is the precision. The `Accuracy` or the `Precision` can either be defined as attribute values, for example when they have fixed values, or using another facts utilizing the verbs `HasAccuracy` or respectively `HasPrecision` when these values may change through time.
Examples: In this example, `ddp#01` is a `DrillingDataPoint` that has an uncertainty `GU#01`, which is representing a sensor having a Gaussian probability distibution that is described using an `Accuracy` (called `Acc#01`)  and a `Precision` called `Prec#01`. `Acc#01` is a static signal that is attached to `Signal#01`. Similarly `Prec#01` is a static signal attached to `Signal#02`.

Verbs.Name: IsTransmittedBy
Verbs.Description: Expresses that a signal is transmitted by some given telemetry system
Verbs.Examples: EMS DWOB is transmitted by WiredPipeTelemetry

Verbs.Name: DWISVerb
Verbs.Description: This is the root class for all verbs defined in the DWIS vocabulary. It is used to define a relation between a subject, which can be of any `DWISNoun` and an object, also of any type of `DWISNoun`.
Verbs.Examples: `DWISVerb` is not really intended to be used directly neither when defining facts nor in sparql queries.

Verbs.Name: BelongsToClass
Verbs.Description: The verb is used between a node and a Noun, i.e., a class. Semantically it can be considered as a synonym to `rdf:type`. It has been introduced to overcome limitations from OPC-UA that does not allow for multiple inheritance. Note that the same node can be in relation using `BelongsToClass` to several classes.

Verbs.Name: IsOfMechanicalStiffnessType
Verbs.Description: A relation to describe how the drill-stem mechanical model manage stiffness.

Verbs.Name: HasUncertainty
Verbs.Description: This verb allows to associate a `SignalUncertainty` to a `DrillingDataPoint`.

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyAccuracy
Verbs.Description: This verb allows to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Accuracy` of a `SensorUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyPrecision
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Precision` of a `SensorUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyMin
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Min` value of `MinMaxUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyMax
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Max` value of a `MinMaxUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyMean
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Mean` value of a `GaussianUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyStandardDeviation
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `StandardDeviation` value of a `GaussianUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasProportionError
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `ProportionError` value of a `FullScaleUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasFullScale
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associate a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `FullScale` value of a `FullScaleUncertainty`

Verbs.Name: HasUncertaintyHistogram
Verbs.Description: This verb is used to associated a `DrillingDataPoint` as the `Histogram` value of a `GenericUncertainty`
